doc.field: The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a><strong> is one of the most famous monuments in <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><strong>. It stands in the centre of the <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPlace_de_l'Étoile" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Place Charles de Gaulle<a><strong> (originally named <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPlace_de_l'Étoile" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Place de l'Étoile<a><strong>), at the western end of the <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Avenue des Champs-Élysées<a><strong>. The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe<a><strong> ("Triumphal Arch") honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. See <a href"#en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>

The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a><strong> is one of the most famous monuments in <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><strong>. The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe<a><strong> ("Triumphal Arch") honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. See <a href"#en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>

Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. See <a href"#en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>
View from the Arc de Triomphe, Paris

The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile is one of the most famous monuments in Paris. It stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle (originally named Place de l'Étoile), at the western end of the Champs-Élysées. The Arc de Triomphe (Triumphal Arch) honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>
View from the Arc de Triomphe

The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe<a><strong> ("Triumphal Arch") honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Pont Alexandre III<a><b> is an arch bridge that spans the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiSeine" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Seine<a><b>, connecting the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Champs-Élysées<a><b> quarter and the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiLes_Invalides" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Invalides<a><b> and <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><b>. Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

<b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Pont Alexandre III<a><b> is an arch bridge that spans the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiSeine" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Seine<a><b>, connecting the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Champs-Élysées<a><b> quarter and the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiLes_Invalides" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Invalides<a><b> and <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><b>. Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

<b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Pont Alexandre III<a><b> is an arch bridge that spans the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiSeine" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Seine<a><b>, connecting the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Champs-Élysées<a><b> quarter and the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiLes_Invalides" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Invalides<a><b> and <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><b>. Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

The <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> (<b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">La Tour Eiffel<a><b>) is an iron lattice tower located on the Champ de Mars in Paris, named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower. Erected in 1889 as the entrance arch to the 1889 World's Fair, it has become both a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognizable structures in the world. <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Tower<a><b> is the tallest structure in Paris and the most-visited paid monument in the world; 7.1 million people ascended it in 2011. The third level observatory's upper platform is at 279.11 metres the highest accessible to the public in the European Union. The tower received its 250 millionth visitor in 2010. Source: <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Wikipedia.<a><b>
The Eiffel Tower from Pont Alexandre III, Paris
